meeting_annotations.speaker: Doug Shepherd
meeting_annotations.transcript: the fundamental optical physics sort of issue here, right, of of scaling forward and then as you leave optical physics and you go to MR or you go to, you know, acoustic methods, like there's all sorts of issues and so I I guess for me I I think the data integration is super important and obviously we work on it, but I think there's there's still probably things that can fundamentally be done from the imaging side to improve our ability to bridge the scales. And I mean I guess I'd be interested in hearing from people that work on bigger things, like how do you get more resolution or what would you need from us to to make it work better for you.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Benjamin Bartelle
meeting_annotations.transcript: I have opinions but I'm I'm filling out the slide.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Bozyo
meeting_annotations.transcript: No, I was just going to mention again about this idea of curating and bringing together data sets. I mean just from experience with the um in some of the parasite systems we work with in particular malaria and toxoplasma, they created these these databases that are toxoDB and plasmoDB which were created by a group at Penn and it's been interesting to watch that over the last decade as it's built up. I think the technologies improved, data analysis has gotten better, data sets have gotten larger. Um but you know, that all has been integrated through that interface and all of us that work in that field find that super valuable where you you find some interesting gene or protein and you can go there and you can immediately see proteomics data, you can see transcriptomic data, you could even get any kind of um genetic information of who's done knockouts and it's more like a community that pulls it together but it is a huge effort but I mean it is something that makes me think from an imaging perspective if if people with all these different backgrounds and modalities and data sets could come together in an integrated way, um you know, I think there there's there's really a lot to be gained from that whether or not that could be done with images, I don't know.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Bryan Spring
meeting_annotations.transcript: I just want to second what Doug brought up. Um you know, are there gaps in the the data acquisition and image acquisition between these different modalities where we could fill things, fill things in and make things work better. I think that's a big question. We probably need another hour to get into that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: David Van Valen
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I would say the algorithms that can extract information from images uh work differently than the previous generation now and there are many optimizations that can be made to make those algorithms even more accurate if if one changed um what was being labeled and what was being imaged. Um so there's a lot of stuff that could be done um as far as adapting the um what's being acquired and how it's being acquired.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alexandra Dickinson
meeting_annotations.transcript: I just wanted to also just, you know, get this idea out there that, you know, we're we've been talking all that about brain versus lungs versus kidneys. You know, I study plants. Um but if we're really interested in certain conserved mechanisms, there are other model systems that um have significant advantages for answering questions about dynamics or um how a specific kinase is working or something like that. I mean in the root for example, you can see time across the length of the root. So that's one reason we we work with it. The youngest cells are always at the tip of the root, the oldest cells are at the stem cell. So you can study aging, you can study development in that way. And 70% of our genes are conserved, right, with with a banana. So there are a number of of networks that can be studied in plants that actually have uh relevance for humans and that's just plants right there. many other organisms that, you know, if we can expand the types of organisms we can look into with all of these methods, I think we can address a lot of these challenges um experimentally.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Molly Bright
meeting_annotations.transcript: Hi, can I can I ask something about that? Um I you I think it was you that also earlier were kind of promoting the idea of really running an experiment, perturbing the system, testing a hypothesis.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Molly Bright
meeting_annotations.transcript: And in my mind, the challenge with spanning, you know, the smallest to the largest scale of organism or very disparate organisms is that we don't know how to perturb them the same way or in a way that we could remotely consider similar sometimes. Um, you know, I'm at I'm at one end and I I do not know how to think about manipulating a 14 year old person the same way as an 80 year old person, must much less the same way as a mouse or the same way as a banana. So I I think that I I agree that I want to use imaging in the context of testing hypotheses and putting together imaging at different scales would be a key aspect of that, but my I my conceptual limit is understanding how we could kick the tires in a similar enough way to really learn from that hypothesis testing across species, etc.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lovett-Barron
meeting_annotations.transcript: There is there some way to uh kind of like how we were discussing before registering or combining information from one scale to the other. Maybe the like a key test we could have of whether any of those ideas worked or whether you could, you know, take predictions from one scale and determine how well it works by doing some sort of manipulation at at at a different scale whether you could have uh, you know, something that would predict that successfully well and use that as a metric to ask whether you really understand the link between say molecular networks and, you know, brain activity or something like that.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Molly Bright
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, I don't know how to do that. Um yes.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Matt Lovett-Barron
meeting_annotations.transcript: I I have a quick technical question if we have time. Jazz, uh how uh with respect to this mass spectro uh spectroscopy imaging. What what sort of preparation is involved and how can I do this to a non plant?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alexandra Dickinson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um basically you just need to cryo section it and um then image it as, you know, quickly is, you know, just freeze it, cryo section it and then put it on a mass spectrometer.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Barbara Smith
meeting_annotations.transcript: I have a follow up to that, a follow up question. Can you do also uh liquid chromatography with that?

meeting_annotations.speaker: Alexandra Dickinson
meeting_annotations.transcript: Um you can that's a good question. I would have to think about that. That does not really exist, but there are there is a movement towards towards doing liquid mass spectro or liquid chromatography mass spectrometry. Sorry.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Doug Shepherd
meeting_annotations.transcript: I mean we learned firsthand how hard the plant work is. Someone sent us an arabidopsis with the microtuble labeled to look at the streaming of them and it's a lens. Like the cell wall is a lens. So we have this very high resolution light sheet system, which is similar to this lattice thing everybody's heard about but a different idea. And it just moves the beam and moves the light. And so actually traditional fluorescence methods are not really amenable to like fast 3D imaging in it without a ton of work. And this was really amusing actually because it the guy basically who sent it to us, it was a random collaboration. He's like this isn't going to work but I'm curious to see what you see. And like I was surprised how bad it was. I mean you could actually see the beam like bend completely as it goes through it. So I mean I think there's lots of things like this across fields that can be learned from. Like if we could solve that problem it potentially helps solve scattering issues in other tissues, right? So this has actually got us thinking a lot about how to deal with that. And so it was really valuable for us to see this from somebody else's perspective of like, oh yeah, that's right. Like there are other things than cell culture, right? That we can just are pretty transparent in all for all intents and purposes.
